theory_metadata.theoretical_tradition: Social psychology, cognitive consistency, attitude change
theory_metadata.original_purpose: Explain psychological discomfort arising from inconsistent cognitions and predict resulting attitude or behavior change

telos.primary_purpose: Predict attitude and behavior change by identifying cognitive inconsistencies and dissonance reduction mechanisms
secondary_purposes: Predict resistance to persuasion and attitude change
Analyze selective exposure and information processing biases
Understand commitment and effort justification effects
telos.theoretical_scope: Individual-level cognitive consistency and attitude change processes
telos.domain_applicability: Belief statements, attitude expressions, decision justifications, opinion changes, commitment statements

classification.tier_justification: Predicts specific attitude changes and behaviors based on dissonance arousal and reduction needs

cognitions.definition: Mental elements including beliefs, attitudes, values, behaviors, and knowledge

cognitive_relationships.definition: Logical connections between cognitions that can be consonant, dissonant, or irrelevant
examples: supporting cooperation while maintaining military strength
wanting peace but preparing for war

dissonance.definition: Psychological discomfort arising from inconsistent cognitions

reduction_mechanisms.definition: Strategies used to reduce cognitive dissonance

dissonance_principles.dissonance_arousal: Inconsistent cognitions create psychological discomfort proportional to importance and inconsistency magnitude
dissonance_principles.reduction_motivation: Individuals are motivated to reduce dissonance through various mechanisms
dissonance_principles.resistance_hierarchy: More important and central cognitions are more resistant to change
dissonance_principles.selective_exposure: People seek information consistent with existing beliefs and avoid inconsistent information
dissonance_principles.effort_justification: Greater effort or sacrifice increases commitment and reduces dissonance

magnitude_factors.importance: More important cognitions create greater dissonance when inconsistent
magnitude_factors.number_of_dissonant_relations: More inconsistent cognitions increase total dissonance
magnitude_factors.number_of_consonant_relations: More consistent cognitions reduce total dissonance
magnitude_factors.overlap: Greater cognitive overlap increases dissonance potential

reduction_strategies.change_behavioral_cognition: Modify behavior to align with attitudes
reduction_strategies.change_attitudinal_cognition: Modify attitudes to align with behavior
reduction_strategies.add_consonant_cognitions: Introduce new supporting beliefs or information
reduction_strategies.compartmentalization: Separate inconsistent cognitions into different contexts
reduction_strategies.selective_exposure: Seek confirming information and avoid disconfirming information

step_1_applicability_assessment.description: Evaluate text suitability for cognitive dissonance analysis

criteria.cognitive_inconsistency_present: Clear inconsistencies between beliefs, attitudes, or behaviors
criteria.dissonance_indicators: Evidence of psychological tension or justification attempts
criteria.attitude_behavior_connections: Links between stated beliefs and described actions
criteria.rationalization_attempts: Efforts to justify or explain potentially inconsistent positions

step_1_applicability_assessment.scoring: 0.0-1.0 scale based on presence and clarity of dissonance elements

step_2_cognition_identification.description: Identify all relevant cognitions (beliefs, attitudes, behaviors, values)
cognition_extraction: Extract explicit beliefs and attitude statements
Map knowledge claims and factual assertions
cognition_categorization: Categorize by type (belief, attitude, behavior, value, knowledge)
Assess importance and centrality to speaker

step_3_relationship_analysis.description: Analyze logical relationships between identified cognitions
consistency_evaluation: Evaluate practical consistency between attitudes and behaviors
Assess temporal consistency across time periods

step_4_dissonance_calculation.description: Calculate magnitude of cognitive dissonance based on inconsistencies
dissonance_assessment: Weight by importance of involved cognitions
magnitude_factors: Number of dissonant vs. consonant relationships
Degree of overlap between inconsistent elements

step_5_reduction_mechanism_identificatio.description: Identify dissonance reduction strategies present or likely to be used
mechanism_analysis: Identify actual reduction attempts in text
Predict likely reduction strategies based on cognition characteristics
Assess availability and cost of different reduction mechanisms
Evaluate effectiveness of observed reduction attempts

step_1_dissonance_pattern_analysis.description: Analyze overall patterns of cognitive consistency and inconsistency
pattern_analysis: Assess magnitude and distribution of inconsistencies
Evaluate tolerance levels and threshold effects

step_2_reduction_strategy_assessment.description: Evaluate dissonance reduction mechanisms and their effectiveness
strategy_analysis: Identify which reduction mechanisms are being used
Assess effectiveness of observed reduction attempts
Evaluate costs and benefits of different approaches

step_3_attitude_change_prediction.description: Predict likely attitude and behavior changes based on dissonance
change_prediction: Identify cognitions most likely to change
Predict direction and magnitude of attitude change
Forecast behavioral adjustments to reduce dissonance

step_4_information_processing_implicatio.description: Analyze selective exposure and information processing biases

internal_consistency.cognition_identification_coherence: All relevant cognitions properly identified and categorized
internal_consistency.relationship_assessment_validity: Accurate evaluation of consonant, dissonant, and irrelevant relationships
internal_consistency.dissonance_calculation_accuracy: Mathematically sound assessment of dissonance magnitude
internal_consistency.reduction_mechanism_logic: Logical connection between dissonance sources and reduction strategies

theoretical_fidelity.festinger_principle_compliance: Strict adherence to original dissonance theory principles
theoretical_fidelity.consistency_motivation_emphasis: Focus on psychological need for cognitive consistency
theoretical_fidelity.reduction_hierarchy_application: Proper consideration of cognition resistance and change likelihood
theoretical_fidelity.selective_processing_recognition: Acknowledgment of biased information processing effects

empirical_validation.cognition_extraction_accuracy: Valid identification of beliefs, attitudes, behaviors, and values
empirical_validation.dissonance_magnitude_assessment: Accurate evaluation of psychological discomfort levels
empirical_validation.reduction_prediction_validity: Valid prediction of dissonance reduction mechanisms

predictive_validation.attitude_change_prediction_accuracy: Accurate prediction of attitude modification direction and magnitude
predictive_validation.behavior_change_forecasting: Valid prediction of behavioral adjustments to reduce dissonance
predictive_validation.information_seeking_prediction: Accurate prediction of selective exposure and confirmation bias
predictive_validation.commitment_escalation_forecasting: Valid prediction of increased commitment following dissonance
